bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 1, 1875

div1.p: Reed and Emilie Lawrence are engaged. They anticipate separation for his military assignment.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, June 1, 1875
div1.p:
I hasten to an-
swer your sweet letter, if, per-
chance, I may be able to relieve
your mind of a part of its anx-
iety. After reading your letter, I
was strongly tempted to sit
down, at once, & write to my moth-
er such a letter as would re-
main green in her memory for
many years to come. But don't be
frightened! I have not written
one word to her, nor do I intend
to write anything on the subject of
her letter. For your sake, my darl-
ing, I forbear. Pray, don't think that
I am at all out of humor or vex-
ed in the least with ma. This latest
stretch of her imagination is no nov-
elty to me. Some people like to
conjure up strange stories &
to use them, innocently as they
suppose, for the attainment of
their purposes; and my mother,
(bless her sweet soul!) may be
numbered among those. The fact of
the f matter is, so much does she
grieve over her late separation
from you, her dearest friend, and
now doubly dear; and so much
does she long to have you under
her own roof, and that right
quickly, that she would use al-
most any means to pursuade
you to visit Harrisonburg. While
I was at my sister's, she wrote
me that she was going to write
to you to come to Harrisonburg &
that she would not accept a
negative answer; that you would
have to come, at all hazards. I am
sure that she did not attach as
great an import to her words, as
you have put upon them. She had
no idea that it would make you so
unhappy to be told that we must
be separated for several years.
She merely desired to use what
she considered to be a good
argument to compellead you to visit her.
Again, she said, that, now that we
are engaged, she did not see that
it would be any breach of eti-
quette, for you to come to H. while
I was there! Well, now my darling
Emilie, doesn't this prove to you
that she looks through rather
ancient spectacles, and not
through youthful glasses? But I
am very happy to see that you
have the good sense to know
better- As much as I love you & as
dearly as I would prize your visit,
yet I had rather be absent from
you three long years, than that
you should go over the mountain
during my stay at home! It
would never do, my darling. It would
appear in the eyes of the people
of Murfreesboro as nothing else
than a silly desire to see me!
Although I would know that such
was not the case, still that is
the construction they would put
upon it; and sooner than one
harsh word should be uttered
against your actions by an unthink-
ing Public, I would lose my right
arm! No! my darling, your view of
the matter is entirely the correct one,
and I had already written as much
to my mother. Next summer, when
I am away from home, I shall
expect you to visit my parents
and spend several months with
them. They love you devotedly & would gladly
welcome you to their home. E're many
summers have taken their flight, I trust
that affairs will have taken such a
course that you will be able to visit
H'burg, regardless of comments. I know
if you will listen to my prayers, that those
summers will be very few indeed,
so that, although I should not see you
again before that time, the separation
would be very short. But this leads
me to speak of the probable length
of time that will elapse before I
next visit Murfreesboro. I think
your letter, darling, contains suf-
ficient cause for me to murmur a
little, but I will not- I love you too
dearly to allow any murmuring to es-
cape my lips. Could you believe,
that, after all my declarations of
honesty, that I had concealed one
word or even a thought from you?
How gladly I read the sentence; “No, no,
I will not believe that you would
have kept the knowledge of it from me”.
God bless you, my darling, nor will
I ever keep my plans & purposes
from you! If I had failed to re-
veal aught to you, quickly would I
hasten to throw myself at your
feet & beg that you would reject
one so unworthy of your love.
I told you that I hoped to see you
within 6 months, or at least, one
year from this time- You will remem-
ber that I said that I was igno-
rant as to the rules of the Army
on this particular point; that it
meight be even a longer time, and
this I told you before you accep-
ted me. You know that afterward,
I laughingly said that it might be
three or four years! If I am
incorrect in any of these state-
ments, I beg that you will correct
me. I tried to be especially plain on
this point, so that you could not
possibly misunderstand me. If I have
mislead you, I want to be held to
the strictest accountability. I could not,
for a moment, rest contented under
the idea that I had deceived you.
I could bear anything better than
this! You will, also, recall the fact,
that I said I would write to N.Y.
& find out all I could on the subject.
This I did before leaving Murfreesbo-
ro. On my arrival here, I found a
letter from my friend, Dr Torney,
awaiting me. He stated that he had
not been able to see Dr Hoff, & hence
could not tell me much- He only
knew that in the Navy it was
not easy for a young officer to
obtain leave of absence very
soon after entering the service,
but that it was the invariable cus-
tom to grant a leave to a man who
for the purpose of getting married!
This is certainly some consolation!
In order to find out all concerning
the matter, I will write this after-
noon, to Dr Hoff & will write you, at
once, on the arrival of your his letter.
If it should turn out that it will be
impossible for me to see you for 2 or
3 years (a fact of which I am, at present,
totally ignorant, & of which I have
never written or said one word to
my mother) either we will have to
bear the separation as content-
edly as is possible, or else, my
darling, you will have to make
up your mind to get married soon-
er than you had expected- I do
not expect to be separated from you
very long. Certainly, if I found that
that the time would be longer than
2 years, I could not possibly sub-
mit to it- You are too precious to
my heart to be absent from me
longer than that!

But I'll not writefill all my letter
with separations & absences-
While I think of it, I will speak
of a matter which I had intended
speaking to you about several
times during my visit & which I
had as often forgotten. I refer
to an engagement ring. It was
my intention, if it was agreeable
to you, to delay purchasing one, till
I knew whether I was going to be
assigned to duty in New York
or not. My reason for this is that
if assigned to the latter place, I
could get just such a ring as
would suit me with much less
difficulty than I atcould in any
Southern city. What think you of this?
I want to have your opinion on
this matter, for I do not intend
doing anything without first con-
sulting your wishes.

I have been spending my time
very pleasantly at my brother's -- am
very much pleased with my sis-
ter- Have been eating straw-
berries 3 times a day, & between
meals, ever since my arrival-
Many thanks for your sweet pho-
tograph- it is excellent, but I can't
obey you by destroying the other
one -- my hand would fall power-
less at my side! Besides I will
now have two instead of one to
put under my pillow, at night!
Am so glad to hear that your lame-
ness is better. As some young ladies
have arrived & are calling for me to play
croquet & as my paper is at an end, I will
close-
div1.closer:
Believe me, darling, as ever, your devoted
Walter.
I leave here, Tuesday, June 8th- If you write before that time, direct to Portsmouth, Va-
I shall expect a letter when I get to Portsmouth- Fondly, yours, Walter.
Received the postal card -- much obliged- W.
P.S. my brother & sister send love.
